div.p: P67/732, unit 298, VPRS 3991/P inward registered correspondence, VA 475 Chief Secretary's Department, Public Record Office, Victoria.

The old Police horse, which you most kindly granted to my deparment for use some years ago, is gradually wearing out, and as my departmental votes are so heavily taxed as to admit of no purchase of another horse, I venture to ask, whether it would be possible to exchange the horse for an other,
sic — two words.
such as would not be capable of performing any longer the arduous services of the police. The horse we had through your kindness is exclusively used as Messanger horse, the errands being often so distant in the service, that for the sake of economising time I have to keep one animal for the messenger use in the establishment,

div.p: I remain, my dear Captain, your very regardful

p.style: font-family: Geneva; font-size: 12pt; margin-left: 1.75in; margin-right: 0in; text-indent: 0in;

div.p:
Ferd. Mueller.
MS annotation: 'M 189 referred to the Honble the Chief Secretary. The Director of the Botanical Gardens was supplied with an old Police Horse on a former occasion with sanction of the Chief Secretary. If Mr McCuloch approves, I can supply Dr Mueller with one of the our condemned horses who would no doubt answer the purpose for wh [sic?] he is required. The horse formerly handed on to Dr Mueller by the Departments has been turned out in the Police paddock at Dandenong; he is quite worn out. Fredk C Standish C C Police 16-1-67'. his name: Frederick Charles Standish.
The application was marked ' Appd J McC' [Approved, John McCulloch] and forwarded to Standish on 21.1.67.
Standish replied: 'Noted and returned. A suitable horse has been supplied to Dr Mueller Fredk C. Standish C. C. P. 30/1/67 [what is this symbol?] 769'.
